channel.title: The Hackers EDC bag
channel.description: Hello fellow 0x00sec h4x0rz!! Today I'm coming to you with a discussion topic on EDC bags. An EDC bag is something that you carry with you every day, I.E, an 'E'very 'D'ay 'C'arry bag. ---------- ## The Bag. Alright, so, what's an EDC bag without the bag part?! Personally, I don't think you need an expensive, super high tech backpack...Now, with that said, I prefer the [Razer tactical pro backpack](https://www.razerzone.com/store/razer-tactical-pro-backpack) ($159.99). It's got pockets for all your tech, and a main compartment for a laptop with room for more tech. :smile: Plus, there's an underside compartment with a weather proof cover for the bag. I mean, built in weather proofing?! What's not to love? ---------- ## The stuff inside Now that we have a bag, what on EARTH are we going to put inside of it?! Well, there's a boatload of options, and honestly it all comes down to personal preference. Here's a list of things that would go in my EDC bag: **Non-Destructive Entry:** 1. [Lock picks](https://www.amazon.com/Narrowser-Package-Leather-Titanize-Scissors/dp/B019DN9GVS/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1487401764&sr=8-3&keywords=lock+picks) and [shims](https://www.amazon.com/10pcs-KLOM-Padlock-Picks-Accessories/dp/B013JS7BS8/ref=sr_1_27?ie=UTF8&qid=1487401739&sr=8-27&keywords=lock+picks), because what's a hacker without a little bit of non-destructive entry?! Very useful for when you get locked out of (or in) things. (Varies) 2. An [EDC Hall Pass](https://acehackware.com/collections/everyday-carry-edc/products/edc-hall-pass?variant=1131982416) from ACE Hackware. Need to get into a room without using picks or destroying your banking card or drivers license? This is your tool. Fits right on in your wallet too. ($10.00) 3. The [Proxmark3 RDV2 Kit](http://hackerwarehouse.com/product/proxmark3-rdv2-kit/) for sniffing, reading, and cloning RFID tags. Useful for things like non-destructive entry and social engineering. ($300) 4. Some [T5557 RFID](http://hackerwarehouse.com/product/t5557-readwrite-125khz-card/) cards for your Proxmark3. ($30) **Wireless:** 1. At least two [Alfa AWUS036NH](https://www.amazon.com/Alfa-AWUS036NH-802-11g-Wireless-Long-Range/dp/B003YIFHJY) WiFi adapters. Why two you ask? Well, for things such as rogue APs. You never know when you will have to try and catch someone doing illegal stuff on their network! ($39.99) 2. A [Yagi WiFi Antenna](https://www.amazon.com/Wireless-Directional-Antenna-Booster-Connector/dp/B00VK0FFKO/ref=sr_1_10?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1487405839&sr=1-10&keywords=yagi+wifi+antenna) for when you need to access a network from afar. ($13.83) **Hardware:** 1. A small wireless keyboard like the [Rii mini](https://www.amazon.com/Rii-Wireless-Keyboard-Touchpad-Control/dp/B00I5SW8MC/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1487410352&sr=8-4&keywords=mini+wireless+keyboard). ($17.99) 2. A [USB hub](https://www.amazon.com/Sabrent-4-Port-Individual-Switches-HB-UMLS/dp/B00BWF5U0M/ref=pd_sim_147_4?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B00BWF5U0M&pd_rd_r=G0868T0RTA9KM4413S6W&pd_rd_w=XnlbI&pd_rd_wg=bGkl8&psc=1&refRID=G0868T0RTA9KM4413S6W) for when you need more usb ports [Don't we always need that? Get 5 or 6 of these to be sure rofl]. ($5.49) 3. A [Raspberry Pi 3 Model B](https://www.amazon.com/Raspberry-Pi-RASPBERRYPI3-MODB-1GB-Model-Motherboard/dp/B01CD5VC92/ref=sr_1_2?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1487406007&sr=1-2&keywords=raspberry+pi+3). Who needs a laptop when you can have this?! But no, seriously, stick this in a building and netcat to it from home or build a [portable hacking station](http://www.lifehacker.co.uk/2015/10/30/build-portable-hacking-station-raspberry-pi-kali-linux) with it [I plan on building mine into a silver briefcase :smile:]. (Around $30) 4. An [Arduino](https://www.amazon.com/Arduino-Uno-R3-Microcontroller-A000066/dp/B008GRTSV6) because everyone has one, and there's so many uses for them. For example, need to get in your friends hotel room but dont kave a key? Do [this](https://www.trustwave.com/Resources/SpiderLabs-Blog/James-Bond-s-Dry-Erase-Marker--The-Hotel-PenTest-Pen/). ($16.06) 5. A [Teensy](https://www.pjrc.com/store/teensy32.html) because again, everyone has tone, and they're insanely useful. As an example, here is Samy Kamkar's [USB Driveby](https://samy.pl/usbdriveby/) tool that utilizes the Teensy device. ($19.80) 6. A [laptop](https://www.google.com/search?q=Laptops+for+sale&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8). I'll leave it up to you to figure out a reason as to why we would need something like this. ;) 7. A [toolkit](https://www.amazon.com/Oria-Precision-Screwdriver-Magnetic-Smartphones/dp/B01IVKPTP6/ref=sr_1_2?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1487413126&sr=1-2&keywords=cell+phone+adapter+set) for fixing things, because sometimes things break in the most untimely situations. ($29.99) **Miscellaneous:** 1. Literally _anything_ from Hak5's [Hakshop](https://hakshop.com/). Like, seriously guys. They have some really cool gear. Notably, their [field kits](https://hakshop.com/collections/hak5-field-kits), [LAN Turtle](https://hakshop.com/products/lan-turtle), and [WiFi Pineapple](https://hakshop.com/products/wifi-pineapple?variant=11303845317). (Varies) 2. A USB drive with [Katana](http://www.hackfromacave.net/katana/index.html) on it for a plug-n-play security suite. (Varies) 3. [Password Reset Key II](https://www.amazon.com/Recovery-Password-Better-Windows-Versions-7/dp/B01BO6604S/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1487411955&sr=8-1&keywords=Password+Reset+Key), for recovering your lost windows password. Works on any version of windows from 95 and up. ($19.99) _I got mine for $5 on amazon, so look around. Better prices will pop up._ 4. A high capacity [power bank](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00ZQ4JQAA/ref=twister_B01AI55GD2?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1) for your phone, Raspberry Pi, or Arduino. ($29.99) _I ALWAYS carry numbers 2 & 3 on a necklace, as I use them quite frequently._ ---------- ## That's all folks! Now, I'm sure I forgot some things that you guys may feel is necessary and 100% not optional to have in an EDC bag. Things like an SDR dongle or heatsinks. But the reality is that more often than not, I don't need those things. Although when I do, I bring them along. Remember, this is supposed to be an Every Day Carry bag! _Keep in mind, this is simply what I would put in my EDC bag. This isn't a catch-all list and it's meant to prompt ideas for your bag, not for you to duplicate. (Although you very well may if you so wish)_ **Discussion questions:** 1. What are some things you would put in your EDC that aren't on this list? 2. Do you have an EDC bag already? 3. Are you enjoying your time here at 0x00sec?

item.title: The Hackers EDC bag
item.dc:creator: sprtn
item.description:
If any of you folks are interested in what I carry for my red team engagements:

NOTE: Entry tools are not legal everywhere. Before I go on an engagement, I make sure I know the relevant laws.

Bag

GoRuck GR1 - This bag is tough as nails, and big enough to carry all the gear I need. Whether I’m sneaking in late at night, crawling under fences, or talking my way into an office, I carry everything I need. It’s not flashy, so it doesn’t draw unwanted attention.

Important caveat: It has limited internal organization, so you need to buy additional pouches to keep your gear organized.

##Tech

MacBook Pro - No red teamer is complete without a trusty laptop. The build quality of the MacBook is second to none, even though I don’t know if I’ll buy the newest model. I have a 13" rMBP. It’s light, powerful enough to run my tools and a couple VMs, and solid enough that I know I won’t break it. Also lasts for ~8 hours on battery; you never know if there will be a power outlet.

USB Rubber Ducky - Always take advantage of unlocked workstations. I take three with me on engagements; and set them up to deliver the appropriate payloads for the target environment.

Proxmark3 - Used to clone RFID badges. Can’t break into an area? Clone an RFID badge and use that to get in. Not always cooperative, but always useful.

Anker PowerCore 20100 - Always have extra power for your phone or other mobile devices. The Anker PowerCore is up against the allowed limit for batteries you can take with you on an airplane, at 20,100 mAh. This will keep your devices charged for days.

Bash Bunny - Newly released, but incredibly useful. This is a very dangerous device, the big brother to the USB Rubber Ducky.

Alfa AWUS036NEH - The standard for wireless hacking. Cheap enough that you can afford to break one, and works with every OS out there.

WiFi Pineapple - A lot of people consider this a script kiddy tool, but it’s very useful for real red teaming as well. Karma attacks, wireless sniffing, MitM capabilities… You can be dangerous with one of these.

Flash drives - You never know when you’ll need to move files around. I keep at least 2x32GB flash drives with me.

External hard drive - Big enough to keep backups of my laptop if anything goes wrong. Never used for client data.

##Entry Tools
Under-door tool - Not a very well-known tool outside of the physical security space, but it’s incredibly useful in most office environments. Gets you into practically any lever-handled door, locked or not.

Compressed air - If you think there will be doors with REX (request to exit) sensors, compressed air is a simple way to trick the sensor. Turn the can upside down, and spray a cloud of cold propellant to trick the sensor.

Snap gun - My picking skills aren’t the greatest, but this makes up for that (somewhat). If I don’t want to take the time to pick a lock, and I can afford a bit of noise, this is a quick way to pick certain locks.

Lockpicks - Lockpicks are sometimes necessary to get into a target facility. I’m no pro, but I always keep a set with me on engagements.

##Miscellaneous

Notebook - Always be ready to write important details down, whether or not your laptop is out.

Flashlight - Always have a small, bright flashlight. When you’re operating at night, you may need to see where you’re going. Also helps if the power goes out.

T5557 RFID Cards - These cards allow you to emulate low-frequency RFID badges. These are what you write cloned badges to.

Mifare Chinese Magic Cards - Sometimes you’ll come across an organization that makes use of high-frequency Mifare RFID badges. These cards are rewriteable Mifare cards that let you clone Mifare badges.

That’s pretty much everything that I carry with me on my engagements; if I come up with something that I’ve forgotten, I’ll be sure to add it in.
